H0.text: Increasing oxygen levels is the most likely way that using fossil fuels in the United States will contribute to rising sea levels globally, according to scientists who have recorded data on global temperature changes over the last 150 years and predicted possible sea‑level changes that may affect Maryland residents.

H1.text: Decreasing oxygen levels are the most likely factor contributing to rising sea levels globally, as increased fossil fuel use in the United States over the last 150 years has raised carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, leading to global warming and predicted sea level changes that may affect Maryland residents.

H2.text: Increasing carbon dioxide levels, caused by using fossil fuels in the United States over the last 150 years, is most likely to contribute to rising sea levels globally, potentially affecting Maryland residents.

H3.text: Decreasing carbon dioxide levels is the way that using fossil fuels in the United States will most likely contribute to rising sea levels globally.

A4.text: Burning fossil fuels is the main cause of these increased CO2 concentrations, which are the primary cause of climate change.

A5.text: Carbon dioxide is a trace gas in Earth's atmosphere at 428 parts per million (ppm), or about 0.043% (as of July 2025) having risen from pre‑industrial levels of 280 ppm or about 0.028%.
